content:
robin_penny said
The one big problem I have regularly with Thunderbird is losing important messages because they are hidden away in a thread. Even if I have marked them with a star this doesn't help them to be visible in my inbox. Instead I am having to guess at a suitable search term to find these messages

What about searching for stared messages?

(often support from Email addresses I do not normally correspond with). I realise I can (in theory) switch threading off (although this didn't seem to actually work for me), but I otherwise like the feature - once I have found the message, it's great to see the thread.

There are multiple methods to remove threading. One uses hidden preferences to change the default for new folders. Otherwise it is something that is managed in the sorting of the individual folder. On the menu select View > Sortby > unthreaded

I would like to be able to show threads in a different colour to make them stand out in my mailbox - I realise there is a small grey symbol against threads, but this isn't very visible and doesn't seem to help.

Try tagging mail either as well as or instead of marking with a star. If your tagged email is in a thread, the thread when collapsed appears in the list in the tag colour.

This very old topic covers how t highlight the collapsed thread. It is a little technical, but should still function the same. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1022969

One other possibility that might be even better, is to expand threads with unread messages, but I couldn't see a way to do this either. 
 Or this addon which marks the current thread read and moves to the next with unread mail.

https://addons.thunderbird.net/fr/thunderbird/addon/next-unread-thread/
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Perhaps you could explain what hidden mode is? It is ok, I googled this windows scripting/ Powershell command and learned that the ,0 parameter is to invoke a hidden window style.

This is most certainly not the forum to get assistance with how this windows feature works, but I would guess that while the process start issues a hidden command of some sort it would not apply to windows opened by the process that is started.

What are you really trying to achieve here?

content:
Tabs at this time are a sleigh of hand. They do not exist as such and are simulated by, as you observe, loading and reloading the content under the tabs.

My understanding is that the next much hyped release (115), which not only redesigns all the layouts but also changes the underlying technology, might also bring real tabs with it.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
When you signed up for what?

Are you on paid or free Mailfence?

If you're on free Mailfence, why not just close that account and install Thunderbird and set it up?

Are you using Mailfence with Gmail currently?
creator: danawilson001

content: Since Mailfence is an email provider and Thunderbird is an email client, you can use Thunderbird to access your Mailfence account. I think the server settings are imap dot mailfence dot com for incoming and smtp dot mailfence dot com for SMTP. Both use SSL/TLS I believe.

content: Although I haven't seen this message before, I do know that Gmail is tightening up security, as others have posted about difficulty in sending to Gmail. In their cases, the issue was insufficient security on email host servers. That doesn't solve your concern, but I believe your error message received may be part of their heightened security.
creator: davidsk

content:
I suspect the error message continues with something like: Diagnostic-Code: smtp; 550-5.7.26 This mail is unauthenticated, which poses a security risk to the

That's what I was getting, anyway. For me, a partial fix was to go into Tools, Account settings, then for my default identity enter my email address as given per my network provider, relegating my usual email address to the reply-to-address. Previously I had used [edited] @psaa.me.uk for the Email Address field and left the Reply-to field blank.

Now the recipient gets to see my email as provided by my network provider, but paul@.... comes up when he drafts his response. But at least my email gets through!

content: There is some confusion on the topic. Outlook does support POP and IMAP, but I think Godaddy was switching to the Exchange server support. If so, you need to add an addon that supports Exchange. There are two: OWL or EXQUILLA. There should be no loss of data as Godaddy should be handling the safety of the account. Your settings will need to change, using direction from the selected addon.
creator: davidsk

content: To clear the password that Thunderbird has on file, do this: - highlight account in left pane on main window - rightclick and select settings - click 'privacy & security' - click 'saved passwords' and then 'show passwords' - highlight the two rows for the account and delete them. - at this point, Thunderbird has no password for you.
creator: davidsk

content: I cleared out the passwords, but it still asks for one. Hitting OK without entering a password doesn't work. Trying various passwords I've used doesn't work.
creator: johnrp9265

content: It may be that a special password is needed for an email client. This is becoming the norm. This site may assist" https://www.xfinity.com/support/articles/two-step-verification-xfinity-app-setup
creator: davidsk

content:
The same thing happened to me this morning. My email account is a POP3 account that I got free from GoDaddy years ago. They have since sold it to Microsoft and now I have to pay an annual fee for it.

I got an email a few weeks ago that Microsoft would no longer accept Basic Authorization from email apps like Thunderbird, and if I didn't change it my email would be shut off on June 2, 2023. They also made it sound like you had to switch your account from POP3 to Exchange, but further reading led me to believe this was not true for Thunderbird, since Thunderbird can use OAuth2 authentication. So I switched both the incoming and outgoing servers to OAuth2. They both worked fine, and June 2 came and went with no problems.

Now it is June 9 and I am getting the same message as you for my incoming server, but my outgoing server is still working just fine. I am holding off switching my account to Exchange because it has limitations I don't like, and POP3 is perfect for me. I am hoping someone comes up with a solution. Until then I am using Outlook on the web.

Also my phone email, the Samsung Email app on my Galaxy android, also stopped syncing. So it's not just Thunderbird.
creator: steve355

content: I think you will do better by contacting the vendor for support. Or try the English version, although that shouldn't matter.

content:
The error you see is often due to the user clicking the link for the xpi file in their browser, which results in the browser trying to install the add-on in the browser. Instead, try right-clicking the link, 'save link as...', then install the xpi in TB.

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/installing-addon-thunderbird

content: We have had this problem too. Two Outlook accounts - one started failing about two / three days ago the other a day later. I reported to Cobweb (our hoster) and got the 'we don't support T-bird, Outlook looks as though it's fine, it must be Thunderbird' response. Yesterday I was getting inconsistent results to get mail. mostly the Stat failure. Then got start of a download of messages which was interupted by service unavailable 21. I reported this to cobweb at about midnight last night. (9th). No response from them and during the day situation looked unchanged. Having watched TV for a couple of hours this evening, finally had another go and got about 25 messages downloaded on mine and a dozen or so on my wife's. All now looks to have been sorted. Notified Cobweb just after 9pm saying I would fully believe it if it's still ok tomorrow morning!

content: Mine is going up and down. One very interesting data point: I have four GoDaddy/Outlook accounts on two domains. Each domain has a main account and an alias account. One of those two domain does not show the problem on either of its email accounts. The other domain is showing problem with the main account but not usually with the alias account. I decided to auto-forward the main account's email to the alias account so I would at least see the email. As soon as I set up the main account's auto-forwarding, the alias account stopped working and wouldn't work until I disabled the auto-forward. This happened twice. All that said, at this moment both accounts are working.

content:
OK. We're making some progress. When "nothing happened," what happened was that Windows 10 took a picture of your whole screen at that moment, and saved it to the Clipboard. What you need to do then is find a graphics program on your computer and open it and PASTE that clipboard image into the program. The easiest graphics program to find is built in to Windows 10, and it's called Paint. Would you click the Start button and look through the menus you see, and see whether you can find Paint? It may be in Accessories. If so, double-click the name to open it and put your pointer in the open white space, and right-click your mouse and choose Paste.

Wow! That looks just like my screen!

If this goes well, come on back and leave the Paint program open, but Minimize it (up top of your screen, choose the minus-sign, not the box or the X) and talk to me. Thanks.
creator: danawilson001

content:
Yay for you! You did it!

Ok, now let's Save that picture as a file. Click File at the top of the Paint window, and choose Save As.... Choose JPEG Picture, and then, .... you have to choose a location to put that JPEG Picture in. If you can navigate to Desktop, that would be easiest, perhaps. Just save it somewhere you can find it.

Then when you are ready to post a reply HERE, go down to Add images (optional) and click Browse, and then see whether you can find that JPEG Picture you saved, and click its name, and click Open, and the picture will be part of your Reply. Click Post Reply.

If you run into any problems, just tell us what happened, and we can start from there and get you going again.

I'm on Eastern Time, and it's after 7 here, so I think I'll quit for tonight, but I'll be back tomorrow, so post that Reply and I'll pick it up and reply to it in the AM.

Don't worry about it. We'll get there.

creator: davidsk

content: Well, I don't understand the comment about Outlook and 3rd party clients, as there are many using Outlook365 with Thunderbird. But that wasn't the question... Assuming your BT account was POP, you can retrieve the messages by these steps: - click Help>more troubleshootinginformation - scroll down to 'profile folder' and click 'open profile' - exit Thunderbird. you are now in your profile folder. (Note the location for future reference.) - locate the message folders from the BT account and copy them into the Mail\Local Folders folder, renaming as appropriate or desired) - restart thunderbird. (Note: message folders have two names that must stay in sync, e.g., INBOX and INBOX.msf)
creator: davidsk

content:
Perhaps the list disappeared, but nothing that existed was lost. Repair rebuilds the index into the stored messages. If repair removed mails from the list they were not in the file stored in a manner that could be recognized.

That compact was failing would indicate either file contention issues of a corruption of the physical message store. Quite possibly due to an aging or failing hard disk. (New disk can fail)

I have never played with apple products and know basically nothing specific about them. Best I can suggest is use the disk utility to confirm the integrity of the disk before moving on. https://support.apple.com/en-au/guide/mac-help/mchlp2548/mac

creator: ryantkoehler

content:
Have an antivirus installed?

I know yahoo works on windows. I am using it to get mail in a configured account.

That is the classic type of error you see when the SSL certificate being offered is not trusted. Antivirus programs routinely use self signed certificates that Thunderbird does not trust. If you have any sort of VPN then again it may well be using self signed certificates. It is unfortunate, but many in the Linux world use self signed certificates "because they can", this is not really conducive to things "simply working".

Now we have the other part of this.

The message at the top talks about probing the server, so something is fundamentally flawed as it should download the settings for a yahoo account from the web from this XML file. https://autoconfig.thunderbird.net/v1.1/yahoo.com

So I guess we need to determine what is actually happening under the hood as it sounds like your certificate store is having all sorts of issues.

First lets make sure some Linux utility has not tried to change the store used. In the config editor search for the preference security.enterprise_roots.enabled and ensure it is set to false.

Now try the setup again with logging enabled. I talk about the process here https://thunderbirdtweaks.blogspot.com/2021/10/logging-new-account-wizard.html

When you get the log in the error console. Please post it.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
The security.enterprise_roots.enabled is (and was) false

With the Config Editor the keys in your earlier post are not found (I also just looked for "wizard" "logging" etc but didn't find anything that looked promising)... So I can't post (or see) any log messages.

Could regenerating a new ssh key help? I'm still suspicious that Thunderbird "knows" or "remembers" something that's no longer correct.

Also, I did try removing the working account (i.e. "A" in my story) from TB then adding it back. No problem at all. Both accounts are simple yahoo email.

content: I also forgot to mention that both accounts work fine on TB on my Mac. It's just the Ubuntu TB that has the authentication error.
creator: ryantkoehler

content:
I found the fix!

The key seems to be setting IMAP authentication method to "Auto detect" rather than "OAuth2" during the setup step. The default appears to be "OAuth2" after TB queries Yahoo at the start of the setup process. The final authentication method then shows up as "Normal password" (when looking at account settings to already setup and working yahoo account).

May / may not matter, but also used a special "third party app" password from yahoo as the initial password, then my normal password (same as if via web to yahoo directly) for the secondary authentication step.
creator: ryantkoehler

content:
No we probably can not help you with your Shaw password. That is set by Shaw and can probably be reset somewhere on their web site. I would expect their support folk to advise you of how and where.

However, requests for passwords that suddenly start out of the blue are rarely password issues. Quite often it is a new version of the software (thunderbird) not being recognized by some security suite or antivirus and blocking the access.

Restarting Thunderbird in troubleshooting mode on a device that is also in troubleshooting mode with networking should offer some clues as to the cause

The message contents are different, so there are in fact the 111 original messages, but they are incorrectly labeled.

(Folder--local "Sent Items"--contains total of 331 messages, same number as original. Errant messages are part of a series I've sent out, and Subject of each starts with same content. They also go to several Bcc's. It's sort of a newsletter.)

content: select one of the emails in Thunderbird, press Ctrl+U to open the message source. Is the correct subject actually shown in the Subject: header field? If not nothing is likely to fix it
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Thanks again, Matt!

Okay, unfortunately, the errant messages have the same exact subject line and time stamp, or at least the two I checked do.

But I have a surprise! Based on your suggestion and my findings, I went back into Outlook, grabbed one of the 111 problem files, and looked at the source: Even though the Subject and date stamp are shown correctly, the source is WRONG!!!! The source has the same errant Subject and date stamp as was imported! I checked a couple more and found the same.

Okay, so re-importing is out. But stepping away from what I can do for a minute to what happened. I think I know: Since I've been sending this series to the same several people, I have created each new message by opening the previous message and selecting "Resend". I'm guessing that Outlook sees all the 111 messages as the same message repeated. (I've done this a few times with TB accounts also [Edit as New Message]; I'll have to look back at their source.)

Back to fixing: So okay, if I decide I can't live with 111 "identical" messages, is it possible to edit the underlying file? I make this to be: 

[Identity]\[profile]\Mail\Local Folders\Outlook.sbd\Sent Items

And more importantly, if I do edit here, is there any kind of character count or coding within the file that will cause me to trash the file if I change it? (I tried this once with Juno mail, about 20 years ago.)

I might have a few messages in other folders with this problem, but those will be only pairs or triplets, so no worries.

Meanwhile, I now know that the present FB import function works, at least mostly.

Thanks again!
creator: mdforme

content:
Okay so a follow-up here:

1. Fixing the data: I was able to save the errant messages to an MBOX file, edit that file, and re-import. This gave me a new/separate folder with the corrected messages. (I've only edited some of the messages, to test it.) I should be able to move these messages back to the correct folder and then delete the errant messages.

I've been able to use Outlook to show the messages with the correct Subjects and Timestamps, and match the Body to relabel the already-imported messages.

2. How TB handles my shortcut: Just as I was doing in Outlook, I opened a previous message, did [rt click] > Edit as a new message, and created a new message from the old. Once sent and stored in the local Sent folder, I looked at the header and it is correctly updated.

So thanks, Matt. We can consider this problem solved.
creator: mdforme
